last_200_tokens: HP:0011920 (Patent ductus arteriosus), HP:0000121 (Platyspondyly), HP:0001717 (Bowing of long bones), HP:0000337 (Broad forehead), HP:0000268 (Macrocephaly), HP:0005942 (Brachydactyly) - The other candidate genes are associated with different conditions that don't match as well: - CYP27B1: Mainly metabolic features (hypocalcemia, Bartter syndrome) - VANGL1: Van Maldergem syndrome - multiple system involvement but different pattern - EPCAM: Ectodermal dysplasia with facial dysmorphism and brain anomalies JAG1 (ENSG00000101384) appears to be the most likely causal gene based on the phenotype constellation matching Alagille syndrome characteristics.</think> Based on my comprehensive analysis, I can now provide the final answer. The patient presents with a constellation of phenotypes including cardiac defects (atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus), skeletal abnormalities (platyspondyly, bowing of long bones, brachydactyly, micromelia), craniofacial features (broad forehead, macrocephaly, large fontanelles), and other features (redundant skin, joint stiffness, narrow chest). Among the candidate genes, **JAG1 (ENSG00000101384)** is associated with Alagille syndrome 1, which involves: - Congenital heart defects (atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus) - Skeletal abnormalities (platyspondyly, bowing of long bones, brachydactyly) - Craniofacial features (broad forehead, macrocephaly) JAG1 matches 7 key phenotypes from the patient, representing the best match among all candidate genes for this specific phenotype constellation. <solution> {'causal_gene': ['ENSG00000101384']} </solution>
